author: abrownguyy
body:
Sure! I’m not an expert, nor do i think I am right above all else with how I do things. I’m not a technical analyst, and I’ve only been investing for about 4 years (I am 26). Everyone’s a genius in a bull market anyway so I’m sure a monkey could’ve performed similarly anyway - but you asked so I’ll share. 

1) only invest in companies you use and enjoy
2) only invest in companies who have forward thinking leaders with proven track records
3) only invest in companies who are building products/services for the future and don’t base your investment on historical performance 
4) don’t buy meme stocks and no one on the internet has the answers I learned this the hard way and am bag holding stocks below. 

I did not lose money on any meme stock. I made a lot off the video game store - this is probably part of the reason I got over confident and started breaking my own principles. 

I lost money on picks made by people on the internet ($FUBO, $CRLBF, $APPN, $FLGT) 

A good example of this would be SQ. I bought SQ back in 2017 when I first started investing. I’ve used their product at the barber, at the coffee shop up the road, at a farmer market. I thought to myself. “Wow, a mobile phone credit card reader for any small business, I only use card so this just made my life a whole lot easier - who made this?!?” 

Jack Dorsey obviously created twitter, and scaled one of the most popular social networks to billions of people and billions of dollars. I believed in him, and he’s a very…. “passionate” individual about the future. 

With the rise in SMB’s (I work for a tech company that serves SMB’s and realized how easy it is to start a biz now a days, I realized that this little mobile credit card processing company was only just getting started, and I bought a couple dozen shares of $SQ (wish I had more money back then). It’s my 2’d best performer behind $PENN (who fits this mold as well). 

Again, I know this is flawed, not-proven, and there are much better ways to go about investing. The 2020 bull run helped make me a ton of money and I’m very lucky in that sense that i invested in companies like $APPL, $SQ, $MSFT, $TSLA using these principles. Confirmation bias? 100%. But I’m gonna stick to it and hope it keeps working and gets me out of the hole I dug by taking the internet’s advice. 

A few stocks I’m currently interested in:
$CRM, $MSP, $S, $FTNT

author: donm527
body: The “blue chips” of past... IBM, GE, CISCO, AOL, BlackBerry... they were blue chips because in their time they changed the world and set the path of progress in their areas. They didn’t fail... they just didn’t predict the next generation of tech or products and couldn’t keep up. IBM... they did pretty good if you see they started with typewriters and made the transition to computers. But Apple taking PCs to the consumer and using a GUI and mouse to make the average person be able to use one changed the world. Taking smartphones from a business only to the consumer with $20 data plan reachable to the average consumer... changed the world. While competitors laughed saying no one will spend that kind of money on it (Ballmer monkey boy) and others said no keyboard it won’t go far (Balckberry). Very tough to be able to lead for that long. Who knew a online bookstore would lead the world in cloud services??

author: abrasiveteapot
body:
There's a long list of companies who failed because of the desire to protect a legacy business despite obvious signs it was getting replaced. Xerox is a great one, but there's also Kodak and IBM (protected mainframes far too long before pivoting at 5secs to midnight), Nokia, Blackberry etc. 

And of course there's the situation right now with most legacy car manufacturers, Toyota in particular. 

The problem with disruption is it happens fast, just ask Nokia. Or look at the number of cars on the road in 1906 vs 1912 (pretty sure that's the right dates, but if not there was a like 5 year period where cars went from a handful to tens of thousands to "everywhere" same as smartphones)

author: Economy-Cup5465
body:
It is extremely nuanced. 

\>The thesis is that Tesla is far ahead in its self-driving capabilities that other car makers just can't catch up. And because they already have cars on the road now, they are collecting more data which is making their lead wider.

It is my view that the FSD tech would be more of an open space. Most of these companies will start using third party companies, akin to how PC manufacturers used Windows from Microsoft instead of creating their own OS. Initially some will try their hand at the market with their own bespoke solution(like the wild west days of 80's when we had commodores and sinclair spectrums). However after some time their will be a standardization(IBM PC). 

At best I can see Tesla becoming like the Macintoshes:  
Tesla: Proprietary full self driving system:: Macintoshes : Proprietary OSes

\>If any company is way ahead in self-driving, it's actually Waymo, not Tesla. They just launched a self-driving taxi service in San Francisco, a dense city with weird roads and many pedestrians.  
Tesla is boasting about FSD(which is between a very good cruise and a poor self driver). The key difference between waymo and tesla is that tesla is heavily reliant on an AI based system, whereas waymo(which does use AI) is heavily dependent on Geolocation and real time data.

\]>The thesis is that Tesla is far ahead in its self-driving capabilities that other car makers just can't catch up. And because they already have cars on the road now, they are collecting more data which is making their lead wider.

Run away from any person who says that leads are insurmountable. Just look at Intel. Went from being a market leader to being overtaken by near bankrupt competitors(See: AMD)

author: Traditional-Leader54
body:
If you don’t need the royalty payments now I would suggest looking into a retirement account and just let your money grow over the next 40 years. In the US these are tax deferred until age 55 or 62 depending on the plan. 

If you want the payments now I’d look into dividend stocks. They are stocks that pay you money (I think quarterly) based on how many shares you have and how much money the company made that quarter. Think CocaCola, Microsoft, IBM, Apple, etc. Companies that earn consistently and aren’t going anywhere. This is less risky than investing in a startup company for a true royalty that only lasts if the company does. 

Either way talk to a stock broker for more info.

author: rock00888
body:
I don't think technology is particularly high risk or anything. It's not crazy speculative or anything. But what happens if a chip that consumes basically zero power comes out of a start up tomorrow? Or what happens if US anti trust enforcement kicks up? Particularly in tech things can change quickly. Not generally for the sector, but for individual companies. Xerox, IBM, et c. all saw huge swings. Any single sector carries it's own risk. 

I don't think tech is going anywhere. I don't see a way tech changes radically anytime soon, but it's the radical changes we don't see coming that do the most damage.

author: merlinsbeers

IBM made probably the biggest mistake in business history by giving Microsoft and Intel the ability to make computers on the PC architecture without IBM involvement.

They could have owned that whole ecosystem and leveraged their incredible brand recognition to attract the talent that made it happen.

But, if they had, IBM management would have overcontrolled it so we'd probably all be using Macs and talking about PC only in conversations with words like Amiga, Imsai, and Heathkit.

Their executives literally have explicitly stated that they can deploy Foundry fully remotely and don't require remote engineers to distribute their product to medium or small size clients in the last month they have outright stated this. Things like releasing announcements of Palantir foundry for builders or "startups" is excellent proof of this.

Their partnerships with Amazon and IBM are literally just ways of Foundry on apollo AI framework being sold by those companies packaged together with other products to sell to other companies. That's 100% scaleable and it's why their commercial clients are increasing quarter to quarter domestically and internationally. 

They have distribution channels doing their work for them and are objectively not a consultancy company in Foundry. They have shown ample evidence that Foundry works out if the box just fine for enough medium and small size clients to be scalable and I think soon we will see proof of this even for large clients. 

There's zero evidence that will have to slow down and as their TAM hears their brand and learns about their product. There's zero evidence that they are facing problems with scalability. However there has been consistent evidence all year that they have entirely solved it or they have continually gone far in the right direction. They increased expenses because of hiring and releasing Foundry for free during palantir unlock at the beginning of the year but their margins would've already improved if they weren't so focused on growth.

author: Lyrolepis
body:
The problem is that ten years ago, when your backtest starts, Tesla for example *was* a relatively new company, and it was not at all obvious - except perhaps to some domain experts, possibly, but I'm doubtful - that it would have been so successful. 

> If you don’t feel that the market leaders are going to provide good returns moving forward (which is pretty ridiculous to think)

If it was so obvious that TSLA and the others were going to keep growing (let alone as quickly as they have), their current price would already reflect this (just as the fact that TSLA had a relatively low price ten years ago reflected the fact that it was a relatively risky investment then). 

Remember, there was a time IBM was a "market leader" too, and a wildly successful one too (not the only possible example, only the first one that came to my mind). 

Note, I am not saying that the companies you selected are not going to be successful in the future - for all I know, they could well be. 

I'm not even saying that you should not do that: as you wrote, it's just one euro per day, even in a worst case scenario that's not something that is likely to ruin you (if it *is*, you have bigger worries than investing). But I'm saying that I would not expect your backtest to give reliable estimates on the return of your investment.

author: Goddess_Peorth
body:
Nope, I'm reading it in Firefox on a linux desktop.

Having lots of users doesn't matter. Just like, chrome having lots of users doesn't tell you which is more popular in a certain industry. More people using phones for internet than full computers also doesn't help tell you what people use at work.

Cloud services are only profitable in the business to business uses. Businesses using google cloud are more likely to be doing so because they have small needs, they're not spending money on network services. Businesses who have core business "in the cloud" are using AWS, Microsoft, or IBM. Google can't really tap into that business, because their history of cancelling services means that nobody builds their core business on top of google services. It would be a completely insane thing to do.

Autonomous driving is snake oil, because they're using trained AI. That's a dead end for this use case, because what happens when the Dept. of Transportation tells you, "In XYZ situation, you need to do A B and C and never L M or N." You can't! You don't even know how your software really works with a trained AI. It takes a long time to make small changes. It will never be more than a type of cruise control, until companies bite the bullet and put the programming hours into expert systems. (Source: day job includes writing robotics firmware)

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

author: captainthepuggle
body:
Yeah it’s a good question and I should’ve clarified. Each of the 13 national quantum centers have a leading national labs, several partner institutions (universities) and then at least 3-4 industry (commercial) partners. 

So commercial partners are involved with every quantum center as far as I’ve seen. 

For example, Q-NEXT at Argonne is partnered with industry partners IBM, Intel, Boeing, Verizon and ColdQuanta to name a few. 

QSA (Berkeley) is partnered with Google, IBM and QED-C. 

SQMS (Fermilab) is partnered with Rigetti, Lockheed Martin, Janis and Goldman Sachs.

C2QA (Brookhaven) has IBM mainly, and then nearly all the Ivy League schools. 

It goes on.

author: Bamstradamus
body:
DDR5 news might provide a pop, but they would still have to sell the memory.  I have said it over and over on CRSR posts, this chip shortage is not ending any time soon, the vast majority of people are still waiting on GPU's to upgrade anything, especially since at higher resolutions the bottleneck moves from the CPU to the GPU, you can run 4k60 on a first gen Ryzen as long as you have a GPU capable of outputting the frames.

Add to that historically the first set of chips on a new DDR is typically slower then the previous gens top tier, the fact all RAM is essentially the same since their are only 3 major manufacturers and everyone just repackages those chips, GSkill probably outbidding everyone else for "the good chip" at the start again *seriously did any of you even build a Ryzen system, Corsair had like 4 compatible sku's for the entire 300 series chipsets life, Gskill got all the B-die*
and the fact we don't have any real world specs to work with yet I don't know anyone chomping at the bit for the DDR5 release.

I can see the news drop leading to a pop, I do not see DDR5 sales making an actual contribution to value until the NEXT set of chipsets come from AMD/Intel.

author: GraysonMA
body:
When you buy leaps you are taking on a lot of vega exposure which can add significant risk to your portfolio. However, vega gives you a second way to win if you stick to companies that have IVR/IV% near their 52 week lows. [Barchart is a great resource for finding these.](https://www.barchart.com/options/iv-rank-percentile/stocks?orderBy=optionsWeightedImpliedVolatility&orderDir=asc)
I also choose underlyings that have low correlation with each other. This keeps things a little less volatile which is especially important using any type of leverage. [PortfolioVisualizer has a great tool for this.](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SPY+TLT+KO+PG+D+INTC+MCD+VZ+FB+MSFT+NVDA+LLY+NEE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36). Leaps I bought recently are in PG, INTC, FB, D, MSFT, KO, VZ, and MCD. LLY is an solid low correlation pick but I’m waiting for a dip in IV.

author: Economy-Cup5465
body:
It is extremely nuanced. 

\>The thesis is that Tesla is far ahead in its self-driving capabilities that other car makers just can't catch up. And because they already have cars on the road now, they are collecting more data which is making their lead wider.

It is my view that the FSD tech would be more of an open space. Most of these companies will start using third party companies, akin to how PC manufacturers used Windows from Microsoft instead of creating their own OS. Initially some will try their hand at the market with their own bespoke solution(like the wild west days of 80's when we had commodores and sinclair spectrums). However after some time their will be a standardization(IBM PC). 

At best I can see Tesla becoming like the Macintoshes:  
Tesla: Proprietary full self driving system:: Macintoshes : Proprietary OSes

\>If any company is way ahead in self-driving, it's actually Waymo, not Tesla. They just launched a self-driving taxi service in San Francisco, a dense city with weird roads and many pedestrians.  
Tesla is boasting about FSD(which is between a very good cruise and a poor self driver). The key difference between waymo and tesla is that tesla is heavily reliant on an AI based system, whereas waymo(which does use AI) is heavily dependent on Geolocation and real time data.

\]>The thesis is that Tesla is far ahead in its self-driving capabilities that other car makers just can't catch up. And because they already have cars on the road now, they are collecting more data which is making their lead wider.

Run away from any person who says that leads are insurmountable. Just look at Intel. Went from being a market leader to being overtaken by near bankrupt competitors(See: AMD)

body:
AMD’s profit margin is pretty good, they are taking market share from intel and approaching Nvidia in performance for their GPUs, and they are innovating well under current management. The problem with your analysis is you’re looking at book value, you need to look at future growth and both companies they can take market share have a fair amount higher market cap, meaning it has plenty of space to grow if things keep going well for them. To give you a basic idea of investing, there are four types of companies - Dogs, Cash Cows, Question Marks, and Stars. AMD is at the Question Mark phase that is almost to Star. They are taking market share in a fast growing area. The typical investor strategy in that situation is to “buy”.

IBM made probably the biggest mistake in business history by giving Microsoft and Intel the ability to make computers on the PC architecture without IBM involvement.

author: Summebride
body:
Stocks means stock market securities that you've surely heard of, Microsoft, Intel, JP Morgan, etc.

Bonds are a timed instrument where you lend your money to something and they pay it back later, with a slight amount extra.

Bonds have traditionally been for old people as they neither go up or down very much, and are predictable.  

Stocks can change in value radically and have traditionally been recommended for young  people so if you lose a lot of value, you have time to make it up.  

Blended fund just means a mix of those two kinds of things.  

At 23 there's no other choice than stock.  

AAR% likely means average annual return.  So if the AAR% was 4% and you have 1000 placed there, it would have gained about $40 during the year.  

Bunds are have recently been returning close to nothing.  Someday that might change but for now they're pretty much a worthless option for you.

author: LastTradeTonight
body:
I know YouTube is filled with peep calling the wheel “free” money. 

Long term you won’t get the same raw SPY return. 
It’s less volatile and more income driven. Also the capital lock-up is less per contract per 100 shares. 
Straight CC on SPY makes more sense than the put side bc it can get you a 70/30 risk profile with higher income. 


If you don’t care about income and are long-term investor than buy-hold is going to work better than the wheel. 

Personally, when I run the wheel it’s on a large cap with good options volume that has some vol but over all pretty stable. In the past companies like BAC, AAPL, INTC.  I haven’t run it since last year for obvious reasons.

author: Hani95
body:
So I'm actually going to do some market analysis on the direction of the market, and I'd like thoughts and a discussion if possible. Think Socratic discussion. 

In the U.S. I think that the markets are going to soon start a rotation to value, and you can sort of see it starting to occur as bond yields have started to rise, meaning that growth stocks will start to become less attractive relative to value stocks. You've been seeing supply chain and logistics companies like Matson, Maersk, Zim, and other assorted shipping stocks boom during this time period. Commodities stocks in the aluminum sector are poised to outperform, because Guyana just had a coup, and it's a huge exporter of aluminum... Especially to China. With that said, steel and iron ore are the same with exports to China from Australia of iron ore outperforming despite negative relations between these two nations. Both of these types of stocks have outperformed year-to-date, and will continue to do so for the next month or two as forward looking investors look at commentary stating that supply chain, and commodity prices will be elevated well into next week. Finally, home builders have outperformed, and are poised to continue their outperformance due to a massive shortage of homes that will take years to a decade to fix.

I believe in the latter months, in 2022, and heading into 2023 financials will outperform as yields for the 10 year T note rise. First, domestic debit and credit card transaction volume will rise (which bank CEO's , and Visa's CEO, have noted has already started to happen), and this will be followed by international travel spend (Which is very lucrative). This will primarily help Visa, and Mastercard as they have been essentially flat year to date and on a yearly basis. It will also help American Express, and Discover Financial to a lesser extent. Then, credit card balances will grow and forward looking investors will start looking at interest rate hikes by the FED in late 2022-2023, which is the one-two punch that bank stocks will need to see outsize profitability. The strong M&A activity, even in the face of anti-trust scrutiny, is also helping banks. Third, ADP and other benefit provider/payroll companies will do well as payrolls continue to increase, and unemployment continues to go down. The runway is still clear there. Then, there are the mortgage companies where there currently has been a pricing war which should cool sometime in early 2022, allowing for Gain on Sale margins to normalize to roughly 115-185BPS, while the value of their Mortgage servicing rights should increase alongside the yield for the 10YR T notes. Open banking should continue its outperformance, with strong markets in Asia, the Middle East, Europe, and Latin and South America, and growing adoption in North America. Companies like Paysafe, PAG, Razer, etcetera should do well in this environment. Finally, the moratorium on school loan payments should cease very soon allowing companies like Navient and Sofi to regain momentum.

I also believe that airlines will start to outperform starting in Q1-Q2 2022, as flight restrictions start falling away, and business travel starts to resume at a more normal tempo. Personally, Delta Airlines and the budget airlines are my preferred ones. Then, there are homebuilders who will continue their outperformance as they have significantly deleveraged and still have long runways for price to earnings growth. I'd expect dividend increases in the latter half of 2022 to reflect this. Third is General Electric under Larry Culp, who's turnaround efforts haven't recently been noticed, but who's conducted strong execution. From their wind turbines, to their jet engines, to their medical division, there is strong growth to be had and I believe we'll see a spurt in the share price to reflect the reality of 2022 and Culp's momentous turn around. I also believe chip fabricators (and chip designers) will outperform. TSM has been relatively flat in the last 3 months, save for a one week burst of over 5% to reflect the fact that they're increasing prices across the board from 10 to 20%. Intel, meanwhile, is building a chip fabrication plant in Ireland which will be entirely dedicated to vehicle chip manufacturing, which I think will be a success. Finally, I believe the used car (autonation), and new car companies such as Ford and GM as well as Volkswagen will outperform in 2022 due to the scarcity of vehicles, compounded by Hurricane Ida's destruction of numerous vehicles (And the risk that other natural disasters destroy even more vehicles).

The China rally, meanwhile, is unsustainable in the light of the regulatory tempo on the free market principle that China ever so briefly embraced. In light of all these actions, it is my firm belief that  China is, or will, embrace capitalism "with chinese characteristics." The crackdowns are far from over, and I believe the state will go further in the realm of entertainment and video streaming, such as suspending screen time for minors on video streaming platforms (something they already do) to a level consistent to where they've placed video gaming limits to combat the myopia epidemic as well as fan culture. They are also likely to crackdown on drinking establishments, and liquor companies to crack down on the excessive drinking in China, in an attempt to stave off chronic health conditions that could accrue, as well as crack down on companies trying to profiteer off a rapidly aging China. These are just a few sectors where I see potential intervention, but there are likely others. The fact that systematic debt has reached such dizzying levels in China is also worrying, and presents a structural issue. A house of cards, if you will. The fact that JD bought an insignificant sum of shares, means that there is a rally in tech stock shares today is foolish, especially since it's broad based and not tailored means there's no solid shoring. Furthermore, the debt to equity levels for some companies, such as Iqiyi, Evergrande, and other stocks is extremely worrying.

I believe emerging market stocks in Brazil, Mexico, India, the Middle East, and Turkey present better opportunities.

body: TSMC is a fairly well known stock, however, I’m placing my bets on Global Foundries. While there were talks a few months ago in regards to Intel acquiring them, a lot of electronics that don’t require high end semi conductors(7nm TSMC, 8nm Samsung, 10nm Intel) are made using cheap, larger nodes that are less efficient. Global foundries failed to develop high end chips after they abandoned their rnd, but they hold a 15% market share(at last check) in markets which use lower grade nodes. Best part is, that they are supposedly going public in 2022. I personally think that this is a wise investment, though a rather obvious one, as any company which is trusted by the US government and hold a market share in a sector worth billions is a simple stock to buy

author: GraysonMA
body:
When you buy leaps you are taking on a lot of vega exposure which can add significant risk to your portfolio. However, vega gives you a second way to win if you stick to companies that have IVR/IV% near their 52 week lows. [Barchart is a great resource for finding these.](https://www.barchart.com/options/iv-rank-percentile/stocks?orderBy=optionsWeightedImpliedVolatility&orderDir=asc)
I also choose underlyings that have low correlation with each other. This keeps things a little less volatile which is especially important using any type of leverage. [PortfolioVisualizer has a great tool for this.](https://www.portfoliovisualizer.com/asset-correlations?s=y&symbols=SPY+TLT+KO+PG+D+INTC+MCD+VZ+FB+MSFT+NVDA+LLY+NEE&timePeriod=2&tradingDays=60&months=36). Leaps I bought recently are in PG, INTC, FB, D, MSFT, KO, VZ, and MCD. LLY is an solid low correlation pick but I’m waiting for a dip in IV.

author: shortyafter
body:
You don't have anything like Tesla or ARK funds, which is good.  I'm not deeply familiar with most of these companies, so I don't know what their revenue streams or growth prospects look like.  What I can say is that a lot of those names have been trading very high lately... AMD, Nvidia, TSM, ASML, etc. Those companies in particular all seem to have bright futures, but if there is any significant correction in tech stocks, you're very exposed, especially if you bought recently at high valuations.  You'll have very little margin of safety.

And if there's any broader economic disruption, it's possible that not all of these companies make it out safe and sound, or at least as healthy as you'd like to seem them given current valuations.

For example, even good companies like Cisco didn't make it out in one piece from the dot-com bubble.  And old industry leaders like IBM and Intel have gotten hammered in the past two decades, while Microsoft made something of a surprise comeback after being declared dead around 2012.

The point is that if you've bought growth stories, that's OK, but it seems your whole portfolio is growth stories.  It's forward-looking.  Which is the idea, in a way, but IMO you want at least some of your portfolio dedicated to something that is solid in the present, and doesn't rely on a growth story in order to generate or even maintain returns.  The benefit of an ETF is you get a bit of everything, and even QQQ is quite diversified compared to your portfolio.  

I'm new but this is my understanding of things.  I hope it made sense.

author: Overhaul2977
body:
Yes however intel’s revenue is primarily driven by long-term contracts that were written when they were ahead. AMD is now ahead and those contracts will expire. A lot of investors expect AMD to win those contracts when they come up for renewal. Will that happen? Who knows. A lot of US govt. contracts are still being renewed with intel because intel manufacters their chips in the US.

I personally don’t see AMD as over-priced for its potential, but I do believe most of its potential is now priced-in unless a major positive event occurs. I see more downside risk in the event intel makes a breakthrough (although that is highly unlikely for awhile) or a negative event occurs. 

Regardless, AMD’s run up is backed by fundamentals and reasonable expectations. There are definitely major downside risks since it has a P/E of almost 40, but it can definitely grow into that P/E if it continues its current trajectory. The biggest problem with AMD is their value isn’t primary driven by its own performance, but the poor performance of its competitor, which makes the investment a bit risky.
